name: Civic Canopy 2014 Symposium
description: The Symposium is designed to convene a diverse network of leaders in Colorado to build on a common understanding of a collective approach to impacting shared results and launch an ongoing learning community committed to collaborative approaches to community change.

attributes.name: Collective Impact-ish Initiative
values: Full Pantries Full Lives Leadership Institute

attributes.label: Lori Ryan
attributes.organization: University of Colorado Denver School of Education and Human Development
attributes.description: As Senior Instructor at CU Denver's School of Education and Human Development (SEHD) I work in several capacities. As an Early Childhood Educator I teach graduate courses and serve on the faculty/design team for the Buell Early Childhood Leadership Program. I serve as a Site Professor in one of our Urban Community Teacher Education Program Professional Development Schools partnering with teachers and administrators during our Teacher Candidate's internships. SEHD has just launched a new bachelor's degree in Teaching, Learning and Development and I serve on the Teacher Education team representing ECE as we develop program for undergraduates. My interests and research include teacher leadership, curriculum development, documentation of inquiry and learning processes and community/family engagement.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: University of Colorado Denver's School of Education and Human Development Urban Community Teacher Education--Cindy Gutierrez, Director of Partnerships

attributes.label: Lisa Gedgaudas
attributes.description: A Denver native, Lisa Gedgaudas serves as the Program Administrator for Create Denver, a City initiated program of Denver Arts & Venues that seeks ways to strengthen the overall health and vitality of Denver’s creative sector. The Create Denver initiative showcases Denver’s talented and dynamic creative community, recognizes its role in making Denver vibrant and economically vital, catalyzes the sector to become a cohesive collective, and enhances Denver’s quality of life through culture programming and business development initiatives to help them thrive.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you:
Create Denver through Denver Arts & Venues
Lisa Gedgaudas, lisa.gedgaudas@denvergov.org

attributes.label: Shawna Tye
attributes.description: I work in the Department of Health Care Policy and Financing, which is responsible for the administration of the Medicaid Program in the State of Colorado. I enjoy my work because I get to assist the citizens of our State and be deeply involved with Health Care Information Technology, particularly the modernization of the Medicaid Management Information System for Colorado.

attributes.label: Shawna Crocker
attributes.description: I am a Colorado native and graduate of CSU.  She is the Colorado Coordinator for an international environmental education program for teachers and students (Project Learning Tree). She has taught PreK-12th grade science in private, public, urban and rural schools in Colorado and Swaziland, where she served as a Peace Corps Volunteer.

attributes.label: Rich Batten
attributes.description:
I enjoy facilitating learning environments that help others thrive and create a more just society.

I love to explore the multi-dimensions of a problem or possibility, help others celebrate their accomplishments and build upon those by bringing together the most appropriate people and resources to facilitate meaningful change.

Most of my work has focused on generational family-strengthening initiatives that improve child and family well-being. Although I live in the metro-Denver area most of my work is outside of Colorado.  I recently worked with a team of people to transition the Colorado Fatherhood Council to a statewide practitioners’ network.
attributes.sector: For profit project management and communications firm
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: Colorado Fathers & Families Practitioners' Network

attributes.label: Audra Bishop
attributes.description: Audra Bishop is a Youth Health Specialist at the Colorado Dept of Public Health and Environment and also serves as Colorado’s State Adolescent Health Coordinator.  With her Masters in Youth Development, certification as a Level III Certified Addictions Counselor (CACIII) and 13 years of direct experience teaching, treating and advocating for children and youth in Colorado, she has promoted youth leadership and engagement locally, statewide and internationally.  She currently offers trainings on both adolescent and positive youth development, is the adult facilitator for the departments youth advisory council and provides leadership on the departments Maternal and Child Health youth-systems building priority.
organization: Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment
issue area/outcome focus: That Youth are Connected and Contributing

attributes.label: Becky Hoffman
attributes.description: Becky is the Executive Director of the Adams County Youth Initiative and has provided key leadership in transitioning from an unincorporated federally funded grant to a standalone non-profit adopting the proven national framework, called Strive Together.  She is responsible for driving the Cradle to Career vision by aligning the time, talent, and treasure for the partnership.  She has international experience (Australia and England) in growing youth serving organizations and has a passion for systems support to best empower at-risk young people.   Mother of two and wife of one she loves to travel, ski, cook, and read.

attributes.label: David Goldberg
attributes.description:
I’m the CEO of CSMlearn, which has created Core Skills Mastery (CSM), a free next-generation web-based course that facilitates community approaches to college and career readiness.  Depending on the hour, I write code, design curriculum and instruction, meet with the Chief Learning Officer of a Fortune 100 company, help a teacher succeed at blended learning. 

My background is as a Caltech PhD molecular biologist gone bad – first as a serial high-tech entrepreneur (geophysics, image indexing, streaming audio, antibiotic resistance testing, optical networking, etc.) making money, and then as a high-tech social entrepreneur, not making money (the latter being more rewarding).
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you:
CSMlearn Community Uplift

David Goldberg
CEO, CSMlearn
david@csmlearn.com

attributes.label: Full Pantries Full Lives Leadership Institute
Lee Wheeler-Berliner
attributes.description: Fueled by a passion to create positive change and to drive innovation in the social sector, Lee Wheeler-Berliner launched WB Consulting to provide impact assessment, management consulting, and collective impact backbone support to mission-driven companies. He has worked as an executive director, board member, and senior leader in a variety of organizations in Colorado. Skilled in facilitation and team building, Lee brings a strengths-based, metrics driven approach to all engagements and gains the most enjoyment out of helping others achieve their goals. He has an MBA with concentrations in social entrepreneurship and strategy from Duke University.

attributes.label: Steve Kennedy
attributes.description: I contract with Hunger Free Colorado as the Project Manager for the Full Pantries, Full Lives Leadership Institute, a two-year food pantry collaborative sponsored by The Denver Foundation.

attributes.label: Catherine Weldon
attributes.description: Hi! I've been involved in online and f-t-f collaborative community development since the early days of Boulder Community Network (94-97). Since then, I've held director and VP positions in a range of start-ups focused on delivering software solutions in niches such as cable/TV/Internet, online training, and healthcare. In each case, I've been dedicated to bringing people together in use of technology with the goal of community engagement and development. I'm currently director of educational solutions at CSMlearn (www.csmlearn.com). I'm eager to both meet Colorado collective impact enthusiasts and to get involved!
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: The focus of our work is currently in the DC area.
attributes.geographic focus: Love to be working in Colorado!

attributes.label: Aaron Leavy
attributes.description: New to Colorado, I am deeply grateful for the chance to learn about and help my new community by working with the Civic Canopy. I am passionate about creating the conditions that enable people to shape their community - and their own lives. Before landing in Boulder, I worked for The Harwood Institute serving as the Senior Manager for Innovation and Learning.

attributes.label: Joe McCarthy
attributes.description:
I have a system engineering / project management background, coupled with diverse cultural experience and interest.

I am and technical experience.  

My profession and personal passion is to reduce the frequency and severity of crashes on the roadway.

attributes.label: David Portillo
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: Funding community organizing

attributes.label: Erin Mooney
attributes.description: Erin is the Executive Director of Community Enterprise, a small non-profit in South Adams County that works to build the leadership capacity of marginalized residents in order to impact decisions that create healthy, sustainable, inclusive neighborhoods. Erin is passionate about working with diverse communities around issues of health and equal access. Her experience includes founding a Community Supported Agriculture farm, directing nutrition and diabetes prevention programs, training and supporting Promotoras de Salud, managing community gardens, and years of collaborative community work around issues of health, wellness, and equal access. In her free time, Erin enjoys gardening, playing and watching rugby, eating delicious food and spending time with her family.

attributes.label: Lyz Riley
attributes.description: I'm Lyz! I work as the Healthy Communities Coordinator for Civic Canopy, addressing the diverse needs of a community striving toward wellness, with emphasis on healthy eating and active living. One quote that drives me is Margaret Mead’s: “Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it is the only thing that ever has.” My favorite color is purple and I have a deep-seeded love of elephants – for their strength, for their grace, and for their great depth of emotion.

attributes.label: Bev Thurber
attributes.organization: Early Childhood Council of Larimer County

attributes.label: Samantha Tobia
attributes.description: I wear multiple hats as the Education Research Assistant for Office of Children's Affairs for the City & County of Denver. My newest “hat”: I just recently joined the staff team for the Denver Afterschool Alliance, a citywide collaborative of community stakeholder working together to ensure Denver youth have access to quality afterschool programs and enrichment opportunities that will help them achieve success now and in the future.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: Denver Afterschool Alliance
issue area/outcome focus: Out of School Time (Afterschool & Summer) Initiatives

attributes.label: Vangi McCoy
attributes.description: I am a mother,wife and grandmother. I am a lifelong learner and educator. I have taught every grade from preschool through college.  Currently I am the coordinator for an early childhood council, serve on a school board and teach at a community college.  I love living in southwest Colorado and collaborating with partners locally and across the state.

attributes.label: Eileen McCluskey
attributes.description: I'm the Manager of the Carbon Valley Regional Library in Firestone and the project manager in our library district, High Plains Library District, for early literacy initiatives within our Northern Colorado service area.  I lead a team of librarians to support parents in being their child's first and best teacher through our collections, story times, programs, EC areas, outreach, staff training, patron interactions, and child care provider training. We collaborate with the United Way of Weld County in various ways and I'm here on behalf of early literacy for both HPLD and the United Way.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: HPLD is also working on Make Today County, facilitated by the North Colorado Health Alliance.  Contact: Janine Reid, Executive Director of High Plains Library District

attributes.label: Patty Boyd
attributes.description: I was born and raised in northern rural Montana.  I received a BS in nutrition from Montana State University, completed a dietetic internship with the Beth Israel Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts’s  and a Masters in Public Health from the University of California, Berkeley.  I worked in hospital management for many years with a focus in kidney transplantation, dialysis, radiation oncology, case management, diabetes and wound care.  I retired and then returned to work as Tri-County Health Department’s Community Putting Prevention to Work (CPPW) Program Manager in May 2010.  My current role includes partnerships with non-profit hospitals community benefit work, public health improvement initiative (CI process), sustainability of components of the CPPW grant, and tobacco awareness work.  It takes partnerships to make a difference in the “health” of our communities.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: The implementaion of the public helath improvement plan for Adams, Arapahoe and Douglas counties.  It is just getting started and I am responsible for it at this time.

attributes.label: Hanna Nichols
attributes.description: I am brand new to The Civic Canopy as the Early Childhood Initiatives Coordinator and am so pleased to be here! I have a background in child advocacy and a keen interest in approaches that promote holistic health, development and learning for young children.

attributes.label: Ryan Hanschen
organization: University of Denver Center for Community Engagement & Service Learning

attributes.label: Nadine Lund
attributes.description: Nadine Lund is a family leader, a graduate of the Family Leadership Training Institute Program and is presently a Colorado Statewide FLTI Community Liaison and is a Life Coach.   She has a daughter who sustained a sports concussion in 2007 and has presented at numerous conferences locally, statewide and nationally to bring education and awareness of sport concussion management and challenges of brain injury and she also currently serves on the Colorado Brain Injury Advisory Council.  She was active on the Planning Committee for over 3 years and was recognized at the 2012 Federal TBI Meeting with the Individual with Brain Injury/Family Participation Award.  She has testified before the Colorado Senate committee about Bill 133, which helped to generate funding for the Colorado TBI Trust Fund.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: Family Leadership Training Institute- Eileen Forlenza, eileen.forlenza@state.co.us, 303-692-2794

attributes.label: Anne-Marie Braga
organization: Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment

attributes.label: Meghan Ables
attributes.description: After working a while in the youth development field- mostly providing outdoor recreation and education programming- I became frustrated with how our systems and communities fail our young people and their families. In a desire to learn how to make systems work better for people, I completed my Masters of Social Work at DU. During my grad program, I interned at The Civic Canopy and I found that daily at the Canopy I had the opportunity to work toward my goal of improving systems by creating the conditions where people who are most affected- and often marginalized- have a voice about the decisions being made that will affect them. So, I found a way to force the Canopy team to let me stay after my internship- let's just say my plan worked ;)

attributes.label: Paul Casey
attributes.description: Paul Casey is director of Neighborhoods for Learning, a collaborative project of Mile High Montessori and Clayton Early Learning.  This project develops the leadership capacity of parents of preschoolers as they determine issues of greatest concern and bring about sustainable change for their communities.  Paul has worked successfully on a wide range of issues as a community organizer with migrant farm laborers, people with disabilities, churches, schools and neighborhood members in a variety of challenging settings.  He is principal of Praksys Consulting and has served as executive director of various nonprofit and nongovernmental organizations in the U.S. and abroad.

attributes.label: Andy Matott
attributes.description:
Hi,
I am a Colorado native (as is my husband) with two sons who are fifth generation natives! 
I am passionate about empowering youth and worked over ten years with middle school students as a classroom teacher and reading coach, and now am helping provide education programs to teens and families through my school and community engagement work in a non-profit, FRIENDS FIRST.

attributes.label: Annie Ytterock
attributes.description: I am currently an intern at the Civic Canopy through the University of Denver Graduate School of Social Work.

attributes.label: Mark Kling
attributes.description: Mark Kling is Executive Director of the Family Resource Center Association, an association of 23 family resource centers promoting the well-being of children and families across Colorado by nurturing effective, collaborative, community-based services.  He previously practiced law for over 20 years, most recently serving as General Counsel for a multi-national satellite imagery company.  Mr. Kling has conducted business across the U.S. and in over 20 countries, and has worked in the U.S. Senate and the British House of Commons.  He obtained his J.D. degree from the University Of Denver where he also taught as an adjunct professor.  Mr. Kling volunteers for other organizations assisting low income and homeless individuals and families, and enjoys spending time with his partner Dagny and her 13 year old daughter Bianca.

attributes.label: Bill Fulton
attributes.description: I'm the Chief Whiteboard Officer of the Civic Canopy--always trying to sketch out a new way to reinvent the world. I have dreamed of bringing the Canopy to life since college, so I feel incredibly lucky to do the work we do.  I'm a Denver native, went to UCD for my masters (where I met and fell in love with my wife Marcia), and went to DU and Iliff to write a dissertation that helped launch the Civic Canopy.  My kids, Ben and Elena, don't really know what I do for a living but I think they secretly think it’s pretty cool.

attributes.label: Joneen Mackenzie RN, BSN CPS
attributes.description: Joneen Mackenzie graduated from the University of Texas, School of Nursing. She is a former 1st Lt. in the USAF Nurse Corp.  Currently she is the president / founder of the Center for Relationship Education which houses the Colorado Healthy Marriage Project in Denver, Colorado.  She is the author of the nationally utilized Get REAL (Relationship and Leadership) school curriculum. Joneen is also a popular national speaker and trainer. Joneen works in the public policy arena with poverty prevention grants and is a consultant for teen pregnancy prevention and positive youth development across the country.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you:
Healthy Marriage Project reducing poverty and increasing child well-being through strengthening families.
Healthy Relationship Skill Building

attributes.label: Drew O'Connor
attributes.description: I have a background in facilitation, community organizing, civic indicator development, and executive experience. My primary work at the Civic Canopy focuses on building the capacity of local communities to organize around the results that matter the most to them, engage in a process to create effective plans to reach their goals, organize a base of power to change policy and systems, and to sustain a network of engaged partners over time.  I enjoy working, playing and living in diverse communities.

attributes.label: Jackie Florendo
attributes.description: Early Childhood Council Coordinator for El Paso County in Colorado Springs

attributes.label: Ginger White Brunetti
attributes.description:
Ginger White Brunetti has over 15 years of experience in public and nonprofit sectors. Through her vast experience, she has effectively positioned the cultural sector as a significant contributor to Denver’s economic vitality, liveability, placemaking and brand. 

As deputy director of Denver Arts & Venues, she manages a $31 million budget that includes the Denver Performing Arts Complex, McNichols Building, Red Rocks Amphitheatre, Denver Coliseum, Colorado Convention Center and Denver’s Public Art Program. Additionally, she oversees the Denver Commission on Cultural Affairs, a 21-member Mayoral-appointed body that advises Denver Arts & Venues and approves public art.  Recently, she led the development of Denver’s first cultural plan since 1989, IMAGINE 2020.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: IMAGINE 2020 is Denver's first citywide cultural plan since 1989. Framed around seven vision elements -- integration, amplification, accessibility, lifelong learning, local talent, economic vitality, and collective leadership -- the plan provides a strategic vision for arts, culture and creativity in Denver over the next seven years. The plan was developed with the input of more than 5,000 Denver residents, many seeking more arts in their daily lives. IMAGINE 2020 makes a call to action to city agencies, cultural institutions, businesses, civic leaders and community organizations to make this collective vision a reality.

attributes.label: Stephanie Brooks
attributes.description: I'm a policy analyst for Covering Kids and Families -- a project that strives to help kids and families get and keep affordable health coverage including Medicaid, Child Health Plan Plus, and through Connect for Health Colorado. We do this by hosting regular meetings for our Coalition of 350+ outreach and enrollment workers from 170 organizations, and advocating to and with appropriate partners for smart systems and policy changes to decrease barriers to enrollment.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: I also belong to and am on the leadership team for the All Kids Covered initiative which has a goal to get all kids in Colorado covered by health insurance. The initiative is led by Covering Kids and Families, the Colorado Children's Campaign, and the Colorado Coalition for the Medically Underserved and has 40+ partner organizations. One of the main targets of the AKC initiative work is the large percentage (72%) of uninsured children in Colorado who are already eligible for free or low-cost public health insurance (Medicaid and CHP+) but who are not enrolled in coverage.

attributes.label: Jim Stephens
attributes.description: I am a learning designer who is attempting to create a statewide connected learning community. This learning community is modeled after the Learning Hive networks found in New York, Chicago and Pittsburg.  The Hive Denver will attempt to establish partnerships between educators, the creative industries and cultural communities though out the state to generate anytime, anywhere learning opportunities for youth that are interest centered and peer supported.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: Hive Denver, and I am the current leadership.

attributes.label: Beverly Kingston
attributes.organization: CU Boulder - Center for the Study and Prevention of Violence

attributes.label: Caitlin Lindquist
attributes.description: I am the Program Director at Think 360 Arts and as such I work with artists, schools and other venues to book arts programs in a variety of genres. As our mission states, we are a resource for teacher professional development, a liaison between schools and artists, and a clearinghouse of best practices and research in arts integration.  I have experience as a program developer, curriculum writer and elementary teacher, and received my Ph.D. in Curriculum and Instruction at the University of Denver in 2013.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you:
We do not have a specific initiative that we are part of, per se, but I am happy to discuss our organization and programs.

Caitlin Lindquist
Think 360 Arts
caitlin@think360arts.org
720-904-8890 x102

attributes.label: Anya Nystrom
attributes.organization: MY Denver- Denver Parks and Recreation
attributes.description: Hello everyone! My name is Anya Nystrom and I am the Program Administrator for the MY Denver program with Denver Parks and Recreation.  I have been with the City and County of Denver for over 7 years and have witnessed what opportunities come from collective efforts with passionate, like-minded individuals.  I believe in preventative health and wellness, which is why I have spent most of my years within the recreation department working in many capacities, and have a BA in Recreation Administration.  In addition, I have a strong sense for organizational design, strategy, training and organizational learning which aligns well with my other interests.  In just a few weeks I will be graduating with my MPS from the Universtity of Denver where I spent the last two years researching and applying this work.  I look forward to this symposium as the nature of MY Denver relies on the partnerships and strength of community collective work.

attributes.label: John Barry
attributes.organization: Colorado Department of Health Care Policy and Financing
attributes.description: I manage stakeholder relations and communications in the area of Long-Term Services and Supports (LTSS), for the Colorado Department of Health Care Policy and Financing (the state Medicaid program).  The state Medicaid Director, Suzanne Brennan, asked me to participate in this event to represent our Community Living Advisory Group project.  This Advisory Group, created by the Governor in 2012, is developing recommendations for the future of LTSS in Colorado.  Two large groups of interest in this work are people living with disabilities and older adults.  The Advisory Group is a public process and will deliver its recommendations by September, 2014.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you:
Community Living Advisory Group

Contact:

John Barry
303-866-3173
John.R.Barry@state.co.us

attributes.label: Anna Zawisza
attributes.description: I have served as the Executive Director of the Alliance for Sustainable Colorado since September 2013. Throughout my career, I have worked to further environmental, social, and economic sustainability through projects at the Alliance, making higher education possible for low income students, and engaging in the community to increase transportation options for all. Prior to becoming Executive Director, I was the Programs Director and oversaw the Alliance’s statewide programs. Before joining the Alliance in 2008, I spent 12 years helping young people fulfill their dreams of going to college by assisting them with financing their education through grants, federal loans, and private student loans. I completed an MBA at Webster University and hold a BS in Management Science from SUNY Geneseo.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: Colorado Sustainability Collaborative is a network of 19 nonprofits and local governments working to reduce Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions statewide.  Most of the partners in the network are focused on enabling greater energy efficiency measures in both residential and commercial buildings as well as increasing the use of renewables.  Some of the partners work on other sustainability issues that impact GHGs such as transportation and local food.  For more information, please contact Zach Owens, Programs Strategist at the Alliance - zowens@sustaianblecolorado.org.

attributes.label: Lisa Montagu
attributes.description: I'm with The Piton Foundation and care deeply about the success of young people.  By working more collaboratively, I hope we can create communities that support our children and youth to reach their full potential.

attributes.label: Cheryl Reid
attributes.description:
Good Morning! I am the Director of the Crossroads' Office of Prevention, located in Pueblo, CO. I have had my CACIII since 1984 and just received my Masters in Prevention Science (MPS) degree from OU last weekend! I was raised in the Air Force, lived in many places, am married with two wonderful grown children, and love Colorado. 
My team of five newly Certified Prevention Specialist (CPSII's) staff, serves 15 Southern CO counties. We provide universal, selective, and indicated evidenced-based prevention programs and services in our schools and communities and are funded through grants, contracts, and fee for services.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: One CommUNITY Pueblo Coalition, through Colorado Prevention Partnerships for Success (CPPS) Pueblo
geographic focus: 6 counties in the San Luis Valley

attributes.label: Katie Baldassar
attributes.description:
Katie Baldassar is the Director of Lake County Build a Generation. Her duties currently include leading workgroups and steering committees, facilitating strategic planning, researching and implementing initiatives, and writing and managing LCBAG’s grants.

Prior to taking this position, Katie taught for Leadville’s High Mountain Institute and Colorado Mountain College, as well as the East Bay Conservation Corps, the Coloma Outdoor Discovery School, California Poets in the Schools and the University of California at Davis. She also spent time as a reporter for The Leadville Chronicle, The Aspen Times and The Colorado Independent. In years past, she has also been employed as a grantwriter, poetry translator, research assistant, trail crew supervisor, river camp caretaker, chainsaw instructor, editor, and backpacking trip leader. Katie has a B.A. from the University of Notre Dame, an M.A. from the University of California at Davis, and is an Ed.S. candidate at the University of Northern Colorado.

Katie also currently serves as the President of the Lake County School District Board of Directors, where she is continually inspired by the work being done to improve educational outcomes for youth.

When she isn’t working or volunteering, Katie can be found trail running, cross-country skiing, mountain biking, gardening and hanging out with her daughter Isabella and husband Andy.

attributes.label: Sarah Park
attributes.description: Sarah Park is the Director of Education for The Denver Foundation, a position created in 2013 to lead the Foundation's efforts to improve educational outcomes for children from birth through high school graduation in select Metro Denver communities, in line with the Foundation's new strategic plan. Sarah's background spans leadership positions in the business, nonprofit, and education fields.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: The Denver Foundation is laying the groundwork for a place-based initiative in Aurora, which we anticipate as a collective impact-ish effort. I lead The Denver Foundation's initiative and Learning Cohort to End the School to Prison Pipeline - a collective impact-ish effort in its initial stages.  I'm also the Foundation's representative to the Opportunity Youth Incentive Fund, a collective impact initiative by the Rose Foundation, headed by Janet Lopez.

attributes.label: Bryce Merrill
attributes.description: I'm the senior associate director at the Western States Arts Federation. I have a doctorate in sociology, specializing in arts, culture, technology, and community research. At WESTAF, I work on our research and cultural policy projects, and have a senior role in the management of our organization. I'm also a musician and active in the Denver "indie" music community.

attributes.label: Nancy Walsh
attributes.description: I am delighted to participate as a commission member of Denver's Commission on Cultural Affairs (part of Denver's Arts & Venues) that is working on implementing Denver's cultural plan, Imagine 20 20.  I am also here as the Director of Museum Programs for the Denver Museum of Nature & Science.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: Ginger White, Arts & Venues Denver

attributes.label: Stephen Griffin
attributes.description: Currently I am looking for a new way of making a living.  I am currently doing consulting in Federal Government contracting, but hope to move into  studying collaborative decision making and deliberation in community organizations and government.  I am open to opportunities in which I can engage in such efforts.  I have completed a PhD in Communication Studies and a Master of Applied Communication degrees in which my focus was those topics.  I worked in an ageing in community initiative back in 2009 and 2010 and keep in touch with he principles of the initiative.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: I am not currently involved in an initiative

attributes.label: Deborah Norris
attributes.description: I moved to Colorado about 21 months ago and really love living here. In my professional career I have been an early childhood teacher, director, professor, and research scientist.  I was a researcher and evaluator for statewide early childhood initiatives while living in Oklahoma.  I had the privilege of being one of the founding members of Stillwater’s Success by Six/Smart Start initiative.  Graduate students and I conducted the needs assessment that shaped the initial direction of the organization.  I have recently started the Early Childhood Collaborative— a network of early childhood consultants interested in relationship-based research, evaluation, and professional development.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: Not currently working with any initiative.

attributes.geographic focus: Not part of one at this time.

attributes.label: Mandy Bakulski
attributes.organization: Colorado Dept of Public Health and Environment
attributes.description: I oversee the maternal wellness and early childhood initiatives at the state health department, where I have worked for close to 10 years. My educational background is in dietetics and I am pursuing a Masters in Public Health at the Colorado School of Public Health.

attributes.label: Joel Newton
attributes.description:
I am a resident of Edgewater with my wife Hillary and daughters Anna and Norah. I am a graduate of Arapahoe High School, Taylor University and Denver Seminary and have over 12 years of experience in youth and family programs. I also owned my own coffee bar at Denver Seminary and worked over two years in Apple Retail as a personal shopper. I am passionate about seeing Edgewater become a flourishing city for all its residents.

I serve on the Edgewater Planning and Zoning Commission and on the Jefferson County Public Schools Strategic Planning and Advisory Council (SPAC). I also network with other faith, business and city government leaders through CityUnite.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you:
We are currently cultivating a network of nonprofits, local and county government, businesses, schools and parents to foster student success from cradle to career. Edgewater Collective is the backbone entity for this collective impact work. I serve as the Executive Director for Edgewater Collective.

Our focus is on the students, schools and families in the Jefferson Articulation Area. These schools feed into Jefferson High School.

Edgewater Elementary
Jefferson High School
Lumberg Elementary
Molholm Elementary
Stevens Elementary
Wheat Ridge Middle School

attributes.label: Jennifer Harris
attributes.organization: David P. Weikert Center for Youth Program Quality
attributes.description: I have nearly 18 years’ experience in the field of afterschool and have served in a variety of positions throughout my career.    I have worked in direct service for the Alaska Council of Camp Fire USA, served as the Special Projects Coordinator for School-Age Projects with Arkansas State University, Chair and Network Coordinator for the CS Mott funded afterschool network in Arkansas, and most recently as Director of the Denver Afterschool Alliance.  Currently, I work as a consultant for the David P. Weikert Center for Youth Program Quality where I provide training and technical assistance that empowers education and human service leaders to adapt, implement, and scale best-in-class, research validated quality improvement systems to advance child and youth development.

attributes.label: Sarah Hernandez
attributes.organization: Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment

attributes.label: Natalie Portman-Marsh
attributes.description: Ms. Portman-Marsh is the Strategic Operations Manager at Spark Policy Institute, and splits her time between organizational development and project work. Natalie provides strategic planning, road mapping, Emergent Learning, project management, and facilitation for initiatives throughout Colorado in partnership with funders, policy makers, providers, consumers and family members by creating meaningful change around shared stakeholder outcomes. She has served as adjunct faculty at the University of Denver, Graduate School of Social Work for the last nine years and will be Board President to the National Association of Social Work, Colorado Chapter in June 2014.

attributes.label: Lydia McKinney
attributes.description: My passion is early childhood education policies.  I have been working in the early childhood field for over eight years, of which most of it is in non-profit.  My B.A. is in Early Childhood Education and Public Policy from the Metropolitan State University of Denver and my M.Ed. in Global Studies in Education.  I was awarded the Buell Early Childhood Leadership scholarship, which I will start in June 2014.  I am currently a participant of the Family Leadership Training Institute and the Children's Advocacy Boot Camp.  I'm a life-long learner.

attributes.label: Alison McCarthy
attributes.description: I am the current MSW intern at the canopy. I work primarily with Ana Soler on Youth Initiative efforts, namely Colorado 9 to 25.

attributes.label: Meggan Pickner
attributes.description: I'm the Community Investments Coordinator at LiveWell Colorado and feel honored to have the opportunity to work with such a dynamic group of people from across the state of Colorado working towards a healthy eating and active living movement! I'm excited to learn more about collective impact as LiveWell Colorado explores the opportunity to become a backbone organization. I love to bike, hike and generally be outdoors and have a passion for kids and education!

attributes.label: randle loeb
attributes.description: I've been advocating for people who live on the edge in America especially in the Metro Denver Region for more than 15 years.  I work with a lot of social service providers including the Metro Denver Homeless Initiative, the  Colorado Coalition for the Homeless, Denver's Road Home, Advisory Committee of Homeless Youth, Colorado Social Legislative Committee, All Families Deserve a Chance Coalition, Capitol Hill United Neighborhoods, the General Assembly with Colorado Cross Disabilities Coalition, and I wrote a blog called Peoplesadvocacycouncil.wordpress.com.
attributes.sector: I'm a cross purpose citizen advocate

attributes.label: Mekayla Beaver
attributes.description:
I think of myself as: 
Instigator, explorer, questioner, dreamer, cross-pollinator... 

My background is: 
people-centered innovation meets systems change
(**buzz word alert** - design thinking, rapid prototyping, human-centered design, co-creation)

You'll often find me helping people to: 
think differently, experiment, learn from and with their constituents/partners,  get inspiration from other fields, go beyond what they've previous imagined is possible

Ask me more about: 
doing improv with doctors, visual thinking, my war against surveys, purposely acting like a 5-year-old, elephants

attributes.label: Sarah Davidon
attributes.organization: JFK Partners/Univ of Colorado School of Medicine
attributes.description: Sarah is a leader in policy and systems-building related to early childhood mental health, disabilities, family support, and coordination of human services systems and practices, who has provided guidance and direction for 15 years in Colorado’s development of an early childhood system-of-care.  As Director of Community Education at JFK Partners at the CU School of Medicine she has provided leadership and representation to other organizations, boards, councils and committees related to early childhood, and oversees initiatives related to coordination of care and workforce development.  She serves as the interim President of the Board of Directors of the Federation of Families for Children's Mental Health.

attributes.label: Michele Ebendick
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: The Morgan County Early Childhood Council and Morgan County Family Center are collaborating on several projects right now around child development and health. We are just beginning the process and hope to gain valuable information from this symposium.

attributes.label: Kathryn White
attributes.description: I’ve lived and worked in Colorado since 1989. My partner and I have two amazing children (ages 8 and 16), both in Denver Public Schools. I LOVE working for Facing History and Ourselves. What could be better than supporting teachers and developing youth?! I’ve also worked with Mile High United Way, Convio, Inc., American Humane and the City of Boulder Public Library. I hold a B.A. in Human Conflict Studies from UC Santa Barbara, as well as a Masters in Sociology from CU Boulder and a Master of Nonprofit Management from Regis University. I almost became a Master Composter.

attributes.label: Jildi Gentry
attributes.description: Jildi Gentry is Executive Director of Morgan County Early Childhood Council. She has extensive early childhood experience, with over 26 years in the field in many capacities including Director of Large Child Development Centers, licensed family child care home provider, worked with FENWeldCounty/Head Start, as lead teacher and site director. Jildi provides oversight and management of Council Staff, program and systems budgets, coordinates Council work and advises and provides support to Council partners, their programs and work projects in collaboration with the Council.
attributes.sector: Cross Domains of all the above
attributes.issue area/outcome focus: It crosses at least 9 of the areas listed above

attributes.label: Courtney Scantlin
attributes.description: I am In-House Counsel (recently relocated to Denver) with significant expertise in business matters and a deep understanding of the legal needs of regulated and customer-focused industries.  I offer a diverse and well-rounded knowledge base with a proven ability to discover effective business solutions and negotiate results through creative problem solving.

attributes.label: Janna Six
attributes.description: Janna is the Co-Founder and Special Projects Director for the Alliance for Sustainable Colorado. She currently oversees collaborative short term projects that help transform sustainability from vision to reality. By leveraging relationships with community leaders in all sectors throughout Colorado, Janna is expanding the network of partners supporting education, policy, and action on issues such as climate change, green jobs, environmental literacy for youth. Janna has been involved with education about sustainability issues in Colorado for over 30 years.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: Alliance for Sustainable Colorado

attributes.label: Matt Guy
attributes.description: Matt Guy is the Managing Director of the Pueblo Triple Aim Corporation (PTAC) and Executive Director of the Southeastern Colorado Area Health Education Center (SECAHEC).  PTAC’s mission is to make Pueblo County the healthiest county in Colorado. SECAHEC serves 16 counties in southeastern Colorado providing health education resources and support for current and future medical professionals.  Matt has also worked for the Colorado Rural Health Center and consulted with other organizations on community health improvement programs.  He has a Master’s Degree in Public Administration from the University of Colorado, holds a 4th degree black belt in taekwondo, and is Commissioned Lay Pastor with the Presbyterian Church USA in the Pueblo Presbytery.

attributes.label: Marc Eschler
attributes.description:
I am a Child and Family Program Manager with The Mental Health Center of Denver.  I am responsible for our Family Resource Center which provides food, clothing and essential household items to families currently enrolled in outpatient clinical services.  I also supervise our Intensive Case Management team.  We are currently focusing on increasing our Health and Wellness programming to provide prevention services to the community. 

I am originally from California and have lived in Denver since 2008.  I love biking, skiing, gardening and spending time with my wife and two young boys.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: Health Living Skills in collaboration with Access Behavioral Care (ABC) and The Mental Health Center of Denver

attributes.label: Donna Munip
attributes.description: Director of Finance and Operations at the Canopy for the past year.

attributes.label: Devon Buckels
attributes.description: I'm currently leading a network of organizations working for water quality, water protection and water awareness in the South Platte River Watershed.  I have an urban and regional planning background.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: The South Platte River Urban Waters Partnership (the “UWP”) is a locally-driven convening catalyst that fosters a culture shift toward regional collaboration in the areas of Water Quality, Water Protection, and Water Awareness in the South Platte River Watershed.  The UWP supports the individual and collective efforts of its member organizations by providing a place to network, discover and leverage funding opportunities, consider project ideas in a larger context, and add additional capacity to complete larger scale assessments and projects.  The UWP uses Ecological / Green Infrastructure as Framework, including natural interconnected landscapes of wetlands, creeks, riparian corridors, river and floodplains, and critical watershed forests.

attributes.label: Katie Navin
attributes.description: I have had the honor of serving as the executive director at the Colorado Alliance for Environmental Education since 2009, an alliance of over 700 environmental education providers all working to ensure a sustainable Colorado through education.  I have a Masters in Education in Curriculum and Instruction with an emphasis in environmental education and over 10 years experience providing environmental education in nature centers, museums, residential programs, and more.  I have been actively involved in the development, adoption, and now implementation of the Colorado Environmental Education Plan, adopted by the State Board of Education in 2012.

attributes.label: Martin Carcasson
attributes.description: I am a communication studies professor at Colorado State University, the founder and director of the CSU Center for Public Deliberation (CPD), and serve on the board of directors of the National Coalition for Dialogue and Deliberation. The CPD serves as an impartial resource for the northern Colorado community. I train students and community members to serve as impartial facilitators, who then work with local governments, school boards, and community organizations to analyze tough issues and then design, facilitate, and report collaborative projects on those issues.
attributes.sector: I am based in higher education, but primarily do cross-sector collaborative work in the community
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: I work on a number of community problem solving initiatives in Northern Colorado, such as the Partnership for Age-Friendly Communities and the Senior Transportation Coalition. Our local United Way is also utilizing collective impact concepts with projects tied to many issues.
attributes.geographic focus: Northern CO (Fort Collins and surrounding area)

attributes.label: Roberto Montoya
attributes.description: My name is Roberto Montoya and I am a doctoral student at UCD. I was raised in Albuquerque, New Mexico and trace my ancestry to families who have been in New Mexico since it was controlled by Spain in the early 19th Century. I have degrees in Political Science from Colorado Mesa University, a M.A in Ethnic Studies from Regis University, and my research focuses on Critical Race Theory, Critical whiteness Studies, and intersectionality. I’m a beginning triathlete thanks to my wife, an avid Bears fan, and am a father-scholar/educator of 13-year-old girl who attends Merrill Middle School and1 year-old son.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you: R.A.C.E.(Research Advocacy in Critical Education)

attributes.label: Deidre Johnson
attributes.description: A Program Officer with The Colorado Trust, I am responsible for the Foundation's Early Childhood Health Integration Initiative and our new Community-Based Participatory Grantmaking work in the City and County of Denver.

attributes.label: Michelle Jeske
attributes.description: I'm the Director of Collections, Technology and Innovation at the Denver Public Library and am very interested in the idea of collective impact.  I recently led a group through a project stemming from the Asset-Based Community Development model looking at assets for teens in Denver.

attributes.label: Joe Sammen
attributes.organization: Colorado Coalition for the Medically Underserved
attributes.description:
I am the Director of Community Initiatives at the Colorado Coalition for the Medically Underserved. My passion and daily work at CCMU mostly consists of working closely with health collaboratives around the state to build their capacity and help to create a statewide narrative of change. I help coordinate CCMU’s statewide network, the Colorado Network of Health Alliances, which brings together 27 health alliances to share learning, strategies and work. 

I grew up in Lakewood, Colorado and earned bachelor’s degrees in both biology and computer science at the University of Denver and a master’s in public health from the University of Washington. I love working to solve complex societal problems by working in tandem with community members. I own and operate an urban farm in the Sunnyside neighborhood of Denver with my partner Haley. We have a two year old son named Oliver.

attributes.label: Abby English Waldbaum
attributes.description: While home after the birth of sons Max and Joey, I experienced the magic of early childhood.  I decided to go to graduate school at DU and get a master's degree in child and family systems and completely change the path of my career, and have never looked back.  I now work at Children's Hospital Colorado in the advocacy institute and am happy to be involved in the Early Childhood Colorado Partnership.

attributes.label: Alecia Brown
attributes.description:
Mother of three young adults and celebrating 30 years of marriage next month. 
Active in the community.  Mentor in the Challenge Foundation program.
Involved with Families First.  Member of National Charity League.
Politically active in the community.
Deacon at Cherry Creek Presbyterian and Bible Study Fellowship leader.

attributes.label: Gully Stanford
attributes.description: Born Ireland; Regional Theatre Stage Manager; Arrived Denver 1981; Citizen 1985; Scientific and Cultural Facilities District; Denver School of the Arts; State Board of Education; Commission on Higher Education; Since 2004 Outreach and Advocacy for Higher Education; Married to Dorothy Denny (DCPA Exec VP); 2 DPS graduate kids, one a lobbyist, one a fundraiser.

attributes.label: Shaina Burkett
attributes.description:
Shaina Burkett is a Human Services Program Specialist with Denver Housing Authority’s Workforce Development and Community Initiatives Department.  Shaina oversees the HOPE VI program at the Mariposa Redevelopment.  Her work with the HOPE VI program encompasses case management, program planning and implementing new initiatives in the neighborhood.  Shaina is also actively involved in the neighborhood planning process, environmental scanning, canvassing & surveying, community engagement and stakeholder planning for the Mariposa redevelopment.  In the 10 years that Shaina has worked with DHA, she has worked under the Drug Elimination Grant, the Youth Opportunity grant, the Workforce Initiative Act and the Summer Stimulus Work Experience Grant, the Section 3 & ASSET Program and the HOPE VI Grant.  Shaina has a B.A. in Family & Consumer Science from the University of Nebraska and an M.B.A. with a Specialization in Human Resource Management from the University of Phoenix.
Contact Info:
(720) 956-3823 or solson@denverhousing.org

attributes.label: Betsy Kummer
attributes.description: I am the Executive Director of The Partnership for Families & Children and have a background in institutional and systems strengthening. I have worked with nonprofits, schools, government agencies, and communities to build their capacity to plan strategically, manage change, mobilize resources, develop leadership, and engage in self-assessment.  My training, facilitation, and technical assistance services have been delivered in a variety of sectors, including education, health, and emergency response and have been delivered in Colorado, elsewhere in the USA, Africa and Asia. I also have expertise in online instructional design and have created five online courses for the Partnership University.

attributes.label: Ayn Fox
attributes.description: I enjoy developing community by designing programs and convening gatherings that get people to have meaningful conversations and experiences.  I do this professionally with leaders of organizations and businesses and as a volunteer in my urban neighborhood.   The International Campaign for Compassionate Cities captured my interest.  I went thru the process of having LoDo recognized as a Compassionate Neighborhood and am in the process of introducing this concept to other neighborhoods.   This is a vehicle to expand consciousness regarding how we are living our lives and to encourage and support action to enhance our quality of life.

LoDo Cares/ Compassion Denver - local participation in the International Campaign for Compassionate Cities promoted by Charter for Compassion International.   I am glad to provide information.  And here are the web sites:

attributes.organization: Center for the Study and Prevention of Violence
attributes.description: Hi there! My name is Rachel and I am working on the Steps to Success initiative in Far Northeast Denver. I was born and raised in Boulder, CO. I am passionate about LGBTIQ and gender issues, Evidence Based Programs and really good brunch.

attributes.description: I collaborate with diverse stakeholders to define shared interests and strategic vision, develop program goals across organizations, and manage marketing and outreach plans to build relationships with partners, clients, and the public to advance an agenda.

attributes.label: Leslie Cook-Knerr
attributes.description:
Leslie Cook-Knerr is the Youth Master Plan Launch Coordinator at Lake County Build a 

Generation (LCBAG) in Leadville. Leslie works to build community engagement and empower 

residents of Lake County to get involved in the process of taking the community’s Youth Master 

Plan from vision to action. Leslie speaks Spanish and enjoys working with and organizing 

community members around LCBAG’s many important initiatives.

Prior to her work in Leadville, Leslie worked on community advocacy initiatives in Nicaragua, 

Massachusetts, California and Colorado. Leslie received a B.A. in International Relations from 

Boston University.

attributes.label: Kim Desmond
attributes.description: I am a Denver native who attended Manual High School.  I received my Bachelor’s Degree in Sociology and Masters Degree in Community Counseling from Fort Hays State University.  In 2010, I was accepted into the Buell Early Childhood Leadership program at the University of Denver, where I received an Early Childhood Leadership certification and a Master’s in Education Administration from the University of Denver. I have several years of experience in the education field delivering services to parents/children in various capacities, which include management of program operations, case management, and strategic planning/implementation.
attributes.collective impact-ish initiative (if you:
http://www.rmpbs.org/womenlead/ 
Rocky Mountain PBS is igniting the Women and Girls Lead campaign in Colorado by activating a strong advisory board of local leaders who will guide our statewide efforts. We know the project won’t achieve significant impact without a strong, passionate and smart group of advisors – more than 60 to date - guiding the direction of the project. The Women and Girls Lead Advisory Board is comprised of both individual activists and leaders of high-impact community organizations who are serious about improving the lives of Colorado’s women and girls.

attributes.label: Eileen Bennett
attributes.description: I am the Executive Director of Assuring Better Child Health & Development. I am the chair and parent advisor on the Rocky Mountain Human Services Family Support Council. Her passion for early identification and referral of young children started when her daughter Naomi was born 21 years ago. I have worked with children and families in Colorado for 15 years. I have an extensive background in corporate and nonprofit project management.

attributes.label: Emily Sumner
attributes.organization: Agency for Human Rights & Community Partnerships
attributes.description: I'm an optimist who loves to work with communities. I will graduate with my Master's in Social Work in June of 2014, where I will then continue my work at the Denver Agency for Human Rights & Community Partnerships as a Program Coordinator. I have studied both Social Work and Accounting, which has shaped my unique perspective in working with communities. I feel passionate about building partnerships across sectors, neighborhoods, & communities to build a more just and welcoming society.

attributes.label: Jeff Mohr
attributes.description: I'm the cofounder and CEO of Kumu, a platform that gives influencers the tools to track, visualize and leverage relationships to overcome their toughest obstacles. At Kumu, we're working to redefine how teams approach complex issues and improve their ability to develop solutions that last. I also work for the Omidyar Group, launching and managing a variety of statewide initiatives to improve quality of life in Hawaii and supporting the global governance function. Born and raised in California, I love trail running, gummies & good design.
